Chemoselective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde over MOFs-derived M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) silicides catalysts Liangliang Zhang a 1 Xiao Chen b 1 Zhijian Peng a ⁎ Changhai Liang b ⁎ 2 a School of Engineering and Technology, China University of Geosciences, Beijing 100083, PR China School of Engineering and Technology China University of Geosciences Beijing 100083 PR China b Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering, School of Chemical Engineering, Dalian University of Technology, Dalian 116024, PR China Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Catalytic Engineering School of Chemical Engineering Dalian University of Technology Dalian 116024 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Liangliang Zhang and Xiao Chen contributed equally to this work. 2 http://finechem.dlut.edu.cn/liangchanghai. Graphical abstract Chemoselective hydrogenation of CC and CO bonds in the cinnamaldehyde (CMA), was successfully performed with highly dispersed transition metal silicides-embedded in the porous carbon matrix (M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni)) nanocatalysts with a particle size of 8–12 nm, which were synthesized by a facile approach via microwave-assisted chemical vapor deposition (MWCVD) using organosilane and metal-organic-framework (MOFs-74)-templated porous carbon matrix-encapsulated transition metal (M@C) precursors. Compared with M@C, the activity of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) nanocatalysts obviously increases, which can be attributed that the overlayered carbon on metals has been destroyed during MWCVD processing, leading to the exposure of more active sites of catalysts. Due to the inherent electronic properties of metallic active sites in the metal silicides, the catalytic activity of Ni2Si@C was much higher than that of Co2Si@C and Fe2Si@C in the chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA. At total conversion of CMA, the Co2Si@C nanocatalyst was chemoselective for the hydrogenation of polar CO bonds (selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol of ∼60%), whereas Ni2Si@C nanocatalyst was highly chemoselective for the hydrogenation of non-polar CC bonds (selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde of ∼90%). The doping of silicon atoms with more electropositive into metals lattices in the M-Si intermetallic compounds (IMCs) influenced the adsorption of substrate molecule on the catalyst surface, slightly leading to the different reaction routes. In addition, the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C respectively maintain the robust stability in the hydrogenation of CMA. This result provided guidance on the design of catalyst via tuning the polarization properties of the inter-atoms in the IMCs according to the target product. Keywords Silicides Metal-organic frameworks Hydrogenation Cinnamaldehyde Polarization effect 1 Introduction The chemoselective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes to their corresponding saturated aldehydes or unsaturated alcohols is one of the most active subjects in catalysis research, which are both highly desirable chemical products from an industrial point of view [1,2]. Cinnamaldehyde (CMA) as a representative α, β-unsaturated aldehyde has been widely studied by exploring the catalytic properties in the chemoselective hydrogenation of CC and CO bonds. Its partial hydrogenation preferentially occurs in the olefinic (CC) or carbonyl groups (CO) to form hydrocinnamaldehyde (HCMA) or cinnamyl alcohol (CMO), respectively [3]. HCMA is used as the inhibitor of the potato tubers sprouting or for the preparation of pharmaceutical products such as HIV protease inhibitors [3], while CMO is an important precursor in the synthesis of cosmetic, pharmaceutical and specialty chemical products [4]. Because both hydrogenated intermediate products are of industrial importance, it is indispensable to develop high performance catalysts, which are chemoselective to either HCMA or CMO [5]. Over the past decade, the majority of the catalysts used for the hydrogenation of CMA to HCMA or CMO were based on noble metal catalysts [6–9]. High selectivity to HCMA achieved on homogeneous Rh(III)-hexamolybdate/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was reported by Landaeta group [6]. Although homogeneous catalysts are very attractive in fine chemistry, the drawbacks of high prices, difficult to separation and contamination of products limit their applications. Compared with the homogeneous catalysts, the heterogeneous catalysis system decreases the environmental pollution and reduced the cost of catalyst [10,11]. The heterogeneous chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA was widely studied. Galletti et al. reported that Pd supported on polyketone presented 87.7% selectivity for HCMA at total conversion of CMA [7]. Zhao et al. obtained a CMO selectivity of 88.1% at 27% conversion of CMA on Pt/SiO2 catalysts [8]. Breen et al. investigated the graphite supported Ir catalyst that showed a CMA conversion of ca. 58% and a selectivity of 98% for CMO [9]. However, the drawbacks of noble metals such as the high costs, their limited amounts in nature, and loss of selectivity at high temperatures, inhibit their wider application in chemoselective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes [12]. To resolve this issue, great efforts have been made for the design of new catalysts with excellent selectivity and yield. Recently, one of the most effective ways to overcome these drawbacks is to incorporate a second more electropositive element (e.g., Sn, In, Ti, or Zn) for better catalytic selectivity through the geometric and/or electronic effect, especially in the case of the formation of intermetallic compounds (IMCs) [13–19]. IMCs with specific electronic and geometric structures have attracted extensive research interests for their unique catalytic properties. For instance, the Pt3Sn IMCs on SnO2 islands exhibited from good to excellent yields for 12 different unsaturated alcohols, including crotyl, cinnamyl, and furfuryl alcohol under relatively mild conditions [15]. The selectivity towards CMO over the Pt3Sn/SnO2/rGO hybrid reached up to 92.5% with a conversion of CMA of 93.9%. Wei et al. investigated the synthesis of Co-Sn IMCs (Co2.9Sn2, CoSn and CoSn2) nanocatalysts toward chemoselective hydrogenation of citral [16]. The best selectivity over the CoSn sample is 67.7%. Duan et al. reported that preparation of highly dispersed Ni-In IMCs (Ni3In, Ni2In, NiIn, and Ni2In3) nanocatalysts with a tunable size and demonstrated their effective catalytic behavior toward the chemoselective hydrogenation of various unsaturated aldehydes [17]. A 99% furfuryl alcohol yield can be obtained over the Ni2In/Al2O3 catalyst at 110 °C. Ni3Sn2/TiO2 was also reported to be effective for chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA and presented 41% conversion with 100% selectivity to CMO [18]. Other than Sn or In-containing IMCs, RuTi/SiO2 and unsupported PtZn were also tested for chemoselective hydrogenation of crotonaldehyde, the selectivry to crotyl alcohol were 48% and 88%, repectively [19,20]. Transition metal silicides as typical IMCs, possess significantly altered physical and chemical properties from the parent metals due to the incorporation of silicon in the metal lattice, which have been proved to be ideal catalysts [21–27]. Especially, the Ni-Si IMCs as highly chemoselective semihydrogenation catalyst for CMA was reported [22], together with more efforts made to the preparation transition metal silicides [28–30]. However, these methods normally suffer from low metal content, low surface area of bulk silicides catalysts, high cost of devices used for synthesis and huge consumption of energy and time, which limited their further application in heterogeneous catalysis. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop facile and green strategies for the preparation of transition metal silicides as efficient catalysts. Recently, the newly emerging metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been proved to be promising self-sacrificing templates and precursors for preparing various carbon-based nanomaterials, due to their high specific surface area, abundance of metal species, large pore volumes, and extraordinary tenability of structures and compositions [31]. MOFs as self- sacrificing templates and precursors has been prepared as carbon-based nanomaterials for applications as catalysts in traditional heterogeneous hydrogenation catalysis, including transfer hydrogenation of unsaturated bonds, reduction of 4-nitrophenol, and hydrogenation of diverse nitro compounds [32–34]. In addition, MOFs-derived metal nanoparticles (NPs) and metal phosphide as electrocatalysts have also been widely studied [35,36]. However, the preparation of transition metal silicides as important catalyst by this method has not been reported. Therefore, it is necessary to take full advantage of MOFs-sacrificing templates and precursors to prepare the transition metal silicides catalyst with high surface areas and large pore volumes. In this work, transition metal silicides-embedded in the porous carbon matrix (M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni)) were firstly synthesized by a facile approach via microwave-assisted MOFs-74-templated M@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) NPs reaction with organosilane. The chemoselective hydrogenations of CMA were carried out to explore the catalytic properties and reaction kinetics of the M2Si@C nanocatalysts. In addition, the stability of Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C nanocatalysts has been investigated in-depth. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and equipment 2, 5-Dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4DOT) (98.0% Aladdin), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (99.0% Kermel), nickel nitrate hexahydrate (98.0% Kermel), ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (99.7% Guangfu), dimethyldichlorosilane (96.0% Aladdin), NaOH (96.0% Kermel), N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (99.7% Kermel), methanol (MeOH) (99.5% Kermel), cinnamaldehyde (98.0% Aladdin), cinnamyl alcohol (98.0% Aladdin), hydrocinnamaldehyde (95.0% Aladdin), hydrocinnamic alcohol (99.0% Aladdin), decane (99.9% Guangfu), and ethanol (EtOH) (99.7% Kermel) were purchased and used without further purification. Argon (99.999%), hydrogen (99.999%) and nitrogen (99.999%) were purchased from Dalian institute of chemical physics. DI water was lab-synthesized. A domestic microwave oven (WBFY-201) operated at 2.45 GHz with a power of 800 W was used for synthesis. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Synthesis of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts were achieved via the microwave-assisted chemical vapor deposition (MWCVD) (as Scheme 1 ). Before the MWCVD procedure, 0.15 g MOFs-74-templated M@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) precursors were purged under argon atmosphere for 2 h. Organosilane (Cl2Si(CH3)2) was deposited on the M@C sample for 30 min through a bubbler by using argon (40 sccm) as the carrier gas at 20 °C. Subsequently, the sample was treated with microwave for 5 min. After three cycles of treatment, M2Si@C was successfully obtained. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The elemental contents of the catalysts were analyzed by dissolving the M2Si@C samples in aqua regia, and the Fe, Co, Ni, and Si were detected either by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Perkin-Elmer Optima 2000DV) and the contents of C, H, and N were measured by elemental analysis with varioEL lll. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was carried out using a Rigaku D/Max-RB diffractometer with Cu Kα1 monochromatized radiation source (λ = 1.54178 Å), operated at 40 KV and 100 mA. Raman measurements were obtained by an Invia/Reflex Lasser Micro-Raman spectro-scope (Renishaw England) with a 532 nm Ar laser. Nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms at 77 K were measured using an Autosorb IQ surface area and pore size analyser. The specific surface area was calculated by BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) method and the pore volume was calculated from the volume of liquid nitrogen at p/p0 = 0.99. Thermogravimetric/derivative thermogravimetric (TG/DTG) experiments were performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA851 thermogravimetric analyzer. The samples were placed in an argon atmosphere and heated to 850 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min. The morphologies of the synthetic sample were examined using a scanning electron microscopy (SEM) of JEOL JSM-5600LV with an acceleration voltage of 10 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were taken on an FEI Tecnai G20 at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The surface composition and chemical state of the catalysts were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ESCALAB250, Thermo VG). 2.4 Catalyst activity evaluation Before the catalytic test, the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts were treated with 5.0 mol/L NaOH solution at 50 °C for 5 h and then activated in hydrogen at 400 °C for 2 h for the purpose of removing the passivation layer. Liquid-phase hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a 50-mL stainless autoclave containing 75 mg of catalyst, 0.5 g (2.5 wt.%) substrate, 19.3 g of solvent, and 0.2 g (1.0 wt.%) internal standard substrate at 60 °C at 1.0 MPa of H2 pressure. The reaction system was under vigorous stirring (700 rpm) to eliminate the diffusion effect. The products were analysed by a gas chromatography (ECHROM A90) using a FID with an OV-101 capillary column. The details of the conversion, selectivity and yield data for the reaction were described as follow: (1) C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − moles of residual substrate moles of initial substrate ) × 100 % (2) S e l e c t i v i t y ( P , % ) = moles of product ( P ) moles of reacted substrate × 100 % (3) Yield (P, %) = (Conversion (%) × Selectivity (P, %)) × 100% The P represented one kind of the products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts The three-step synthesis of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) is schematically shown in Scheme 1. As revealed by SEM, uniform MOFs-74 nano-cuboids with smooth surface were obtained according to literature methods (Fig. S1) [37,38]. The XRD patterns confirm their high crystallinity (Fig. S2). Thermogravimetric (TG) experiment was performed in argon atmosphere to obtain the optimal pyrolysis temperature for MOFs-74 to obtain the M@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni). The result showed that the complete pyrolysis temperature for Fe-MOFs-74 is 700 °C (Fig. S3a). While M@C (M = Co, Ni) are achieved by pyrolysis of M-MOFs-74 (M = Co, Ni) at 600 °C (Fig. S3b–c). The XRD patterns of MOFs-derived M@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. A broad and weak peak for all samples ca. 26° could be indexed to the (002) plane for carbon, which confirms the formation of porous carbon matrix after the process of MOFs carbonization [32]. The sample of Fe@C primarily exhibits three diffraction peaks at 44.7°, 65.0°, and 82.3°, which are assigned to the (110), (200), and (211) crystal faces of Fe (JCPD PDF 06-0696), respectively. The XRD pattern of the Co@C sample shows three typical diffraction peaks at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.9°, respectively, which is characteristic of metallic Co (JCPD PDF 15-0806). The presence of metallic Ni in Ni@C sample is also confirmed by its XRD pattern. The three typical diffraction peaks at 44.5°, 51.8°, and 76.4° can be indexed to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal faces of Ni (JCPD PDF 04-0850), respectively. The results indicates that M@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) have been successfully synthesized by pyrolysis of M-MOFs-74 (M = Fe, Co, Ni). After deposition of dimethyldichlorosilane onto the surface of metal NPs through the channels of carbon matrix via chemical vapor deposition, the M2Si@C catalysts are successfully synthesized after microwave silicification. XRD patterns for M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts with a range of different metal silicides are shown in Fig. 1b. The peak indexed to the (002) plane of carbon does not change obviously. The carbon structure in the M2Si@C is further determined by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. S4, the two broad peaks at ca. 1344.2 and 1575.1 cm−1 are ascribed to the D and G bands of carbon, which further confirm the existence of porous carbon matrix [39,40]. Meanwhile, the higher sharp G band peak and lower flat D band peak represent high degree of graphitization and expose edge to the graphitized carbon, respectively. The crystalline phases are identified by comparison with ICSD files. For the Fe2Si@C catalyst, the three typical diffraction peaks at 45.6°, 66.4°, and 84.2°, which can be indexed to the (110), (200), and (211) crystal faces of Fe2Si (JCPD PDF 26-1141), respectively. In the case of the Co2Si@C catalyst, four typical diffraction peaks at 44.1°, 44.8°, 45.3°, and 46.0° can be indexed to the (021), (220), (301), and (121) crystal faces of Co2Si (JCPD PDF 04-0847), respectively [41]. The three typical diffraction peaks located at 43.5°, 44.3°, and 45.5° are all consistent with Ni2Si (JCPD PDF 50-0779), demonstrating the formation of Ni2Si NPs after the silicification of Ni@C [42]. The XRD result indicates the successful formation of the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) nanocatalysts. Except for the phase of silicides in the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) nanocatalysts, no SiC phase is found in all samples, which indicates that organosilane was deposited from the channels of carbon matrix to the surface of metal NPs. After microwave silicification, the metal reacted with organosilane to form metal silicides. This result is consistent with the preconception. The possible formation mechanism of the metal silicides NPs could be expressed by the following reaction equations. I: Decomposition reaction (CH4)2SiCl2 → CH3Cl + SiH4 + HCl II: Silicification reaction M (M = Fe, Co, Ni) + SiH4 → M2Si + 2H2 Firstly, the deposited dimethyldichlorosilane on the surface of metal NPs decomposes in the microwave treatment, then the produced silane (SiH4) reacts with metal NPs to form metal silicides [42]. During this process, the carbon shell as a good microwave-absorbing material transfers the microwave energy to the chemical reaction effectively. The morphology of M2Si@C was shown in the SEM images (as shown in Fig. 2 ). The results show that the rough surface consisted of irregular NPs (Fig. 2a–c) [36]. And the elemental mapping results confirms the coexistence of carbon, metal M (M = Fe, Co, Ni) and silicon components. Homogeneous distributions of metal M (M = Fe, Co, Ni) and Si are found in the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) samples, as seen in the corresponding elemental mappings. These indicate that the Si atoms are uniformly doped into the lattice of metallic M (M = Fe, Co, Ni). TEM was performed to gain further insight into the detailed structures. The magnified TEM image (Fig. 3 ) shows that numerous small particles with diameters of about 8–12 nm are uniformly distributed in the carbon frameworks. The metal silicides NPs are surrounded by carbon matrix. This phenomenon is consistent with the literature work that was reported on the use of metal phosphide for the lithium-ion battery anode [36]. Furthermore, it was found that the particle size is ca. 8 nm from the HRTEM images of Fe2Si@C NPs in Fig. 3b. The HRTEM image (Fig. 3c) exhibits distinct lattice fringe 0.199 nm corresponding to the (110) plane of Fe2Si@C (JCPDS 26-1141). HRTEM (Fig. 3d) shows that the sample is composed of Co2Si NPs and is less than 10 nm in diameter which is homogeneously distributed in a continuous carbon matrix. Fig. 3f displays the HRTEM image of Co2Si, in which the d-spacing is measured to be 0.205 nm, coinciding with the (021) planes of the Co2Si (JCPDS 04-0847). The magnified TEM image (Fig. 3g) shows that the size of the Ni2Si is estimated to be 10 nm and is uniformly distributed. The Ni2Si NPs in the Ni2Si@C are highly crystallized (Fig. 3i), exhibiting distinct lattice fringes with a spacing of 0.199 nm, and are consistent with the (121) lattice plane of the Ni2Si (JCPDS 50-50-0779). XPS was employed to investigate the elemental composition and chemical states of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni). A typical XPS survey spectrum (Fig. 4 a) indicates that the M2Si@C is mainly composed of C, O, Si, and M (M = Fe, Co, Ni) elements, which is in agreement with the elemental mapping results. The oxygen peak originates from the superficial metal atoms oxidized in air and Si-O x [42]. The high resolution Fe 2p XPS spectrum shows two peaks at binding energies of 707.1 and 720.7 eV (Fig. 4b), which can be assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of the Fe2Si, respectively. Two peaks in the Fe 2p region at 709.8 and 722.6 eV are assigned to the FeO x , which result from the surface oxidation of Fe2Si. This result is similar to previous finding for iron oxides [43]. Fig. 3c shows that the high resolution Co 2p XPS spectrum is deconvoluted into two contributions. The two peaks at 778.3 and 793.4 eV are assigned to the Co2Si phase [44,45]. The peak at 777.8 eV attributed to the metallic Co does not exist, which indicates that the Co NPs are completely silicified to cobalt silicides. Because of the slight surface oxidation of Co2Si phase, so the peaks (779.9 and 795.3 eV) attributed to CoO x is observed [46,47]. The high resolution Ni 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 4d) shows characteristic peaks centered at 852.8 and 870.7 eV, which are higher than that of metallic Ni (852.3 eV), indicating the formation of Ni2Si phase ascribed to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2. Another two peaks are found at 858.4 and 876.7 eV in the Ni 2p region which correspond to the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 of NiO x [42]. The result demonstrated that the covalent interactions between metal (Fe, Co, Ni) and Si lead to a slight transfer of electron density from the metal to silicon, which is consistent with the Pauling electronegativity scale. For the XPS profiles of Si element, one peak is found in the Si 2p region at 99.3 and 98.7 eV in the Fe2Si@C and Ni2Si@C sample, corresponding to the Fe-Si and Ni-Si IMCs respectively (Fig. 4e). Two peaks at 98.4 and 101.5 eV (Fig. 4e) in the Si 2p region of Co2Si@C sample corresponds to the formation of Co-Si and Si-O x , respectively [48,49]. The high-resolution metal 2p and Si 2p spectra further confirm the presence of M2Si (M = Fe, Co, Ni). Combined with the above characterization results, it is therefore confirmed that the transition metal silicides M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) were successfully synthesized via microwaved-assisted chemical vapor deposition. For the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts, chemical analysis reveals that the actual metal contents are ca. 20 at.% (Table 1 ). However, the actual value of silicon exceeds the theoretical value which is calculated by atomic ratio (M/Si = 2:1) of M2Si phases. The result indicates the component of Si-O x exists except for the dominating M2Si phases, and is consistent with the XPS results. The textural properties of the M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) samples were investigated by nitrogen adsorption-desorption measurements (Table 1). The surface area of the obtained M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) samples are ca. 185, 117, and 168 m2 g−1, respectively. The pore diameters of all samples are ca. 3.2 nm, which clearly indicate that all catalysts are mesoporous materials. In addition, nitrogen uptake at P/P0 = 0.4–1.0 with a hysteresis loop for all the samples (Fig. S5a) indicate that the mesoporous structures are maintained, which are in consistent with the calculation results. Fig. S5b shows the pore size distribution of above samples. The pore diameter of M2Si@C is mainly in the mesoporous range. The pore with diameter in the range of 2 ∼ 10 nm is formed by accumulating in the thermolysis process. In the process of MWCVD, mesoporous are still dominant in M2Si@C samples although the microporous also exists. This explains the hysteresis loop. 3.2 Catalytic performance of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) in the hydrogenation reaction The hydrogenations of CC (styrene) and CO (benzaldehyde) individual functional groups were used to probe the catalytic properties of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni). A simple reaction pathway is depicted in Scheme 2 . The hydrogenation results over the as-prepared catalysts were summarized in Fig. 5 . It is well known that the thermodynamics favors the hydrogenation of the CC over the CO. Fe2Si@C shows almost negligible activity for the hydrogenation of styrene and benzaldehyde with only a 6.8% conversion of styrene to ethylbenzene and almost no conversion of benzaldehyde. As expected, Co2Si@C is a relatively highly active catalyst, not only promoting the hydrogenation of the olefin, but also of carbonyl group. Thus, styrene and benzaldehyde are hydrogenated completely to the saturated products ethylbenzene and benzyl alcohol in quantitatively, respectively. Based on the reaction data, conversion of styrene to ethylbenzene proceeds with a rate of 0.398 h−1 while the corresponding rate for conversion of benzaldehyde is 0.252 h−1 (Fig. 5a), which indicates that the catalytic reactivity of CC is higher than that of CO. In sharp contrast, Ni2Si@C exhibits high activities for the CC and CO hydrogenation, as styrene and benzaldehyde are both almost completely converted to ethylbenzene and benzyl alcohol respectively. The conversion of styrene to ethylbenzene proceeds with a rate of 2.09 h−1 while the corresponding rate for conversion of benzaldehyde is 0.714 h−1 (Fig. 5b), which also indicates that the catalytic activity of CC was higher than that of CO. Overall, these results indicate that both Ni2Si@C and Co2Si@C show higher catalytic activity of CC than that of CO in single unsaturated bond substrate, while the former exhibits higher activity for the hydrogenation of CC and CO than the latter, which is coincident with the thermodynamics results and previous published work. The thermodynamics of this reaction favors the hydrogenation of CC bonds since the bond energy of CO is higher [50–54]. A competitive experiment was further performed in which the CC and CO moieties were mixed into individual substrates. The results of the as-prepared samples were summarized in Table 2 . The hydrogenation of styrene and benzaldehyde over Co2Si@C produce ethylbenzene and benzyl alcohol with conversions of 71.7% and >99% in 300 min, respectively. Thus, the catalyst could simultaneously hydrogenate CC and CO moieties, where the reduction of CO bond occur preferentially. Ni2Si@C could also simultaneously hydrogenate CC and CO group, but shows higher activity in the reduction of CC bond than that for CO bond. When the mixture substrate of CC bond and CO bond is selected, the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalyst show different reaction results. Based on the above result, we put forward a speculation that Co2Si@C possesses high selectivity of CO, while Ni2Si@C prefers selective hydrogenation of CC in the presence of substrate containing both CC and CO bonds. To further study the hydrogenation of CC and CO bonds, CMA as typical α, β-unsaturated aldehyde substrate has been chosen to probe the catalytic properties of prepared M2Si@C (M = Co and Ni) catalysts. The hydrogenation reaction CMA molecule follows two possible pathways: (i) the hydrogenation of CC bond with the formation of HCMA and (ii) the hydrogenation of CO bond to form CMO (Scheme 3 ). The chemoselective hydrogenation towards the CMO is difficult to achieve since thermodynamics favors the hydrogenation of the CC over the CO by ∼35 kJ/mol and for kinetic reasons the reactivity of the CC group is higher than CO group in the hydrogenation reactions. The reaction results are shown in Table 3 . The hydrogenation of CMA catalyzed by Co2Si@C provides a mixture of CMO, HCMA, and hydrocinnamyl alcohol (HCMO) products with yields of 59.6%, 11.6%, and 27.8% after 450 min at 60 °C and at 1 MPa of H2, respectively (Table 3). In addition, Ni2Si@C maintains high activity for the hydrogenation of CC, over which the HCMA yield could reach to maximum of 81.7% after 105 min. It is thus confirmed that Co2Si@C possesses high selectivity of CO bond to produce CMO, while Ni2Si@C prefers selective hydrogenation of CC bond to produce HCMA. The conversions of CMA versus time as well as the yield to the hydrogenation products for metals and corresponding metal silicides catalysts at 60 °C and at pressure of H2 of 1 MPa are compared in Fig. 6 . The reaction profiles of CMA hydrogenation demonstrates the formation of both CMO and HCMA, which is obviously due to the competitive hydrogenation between CO and CC coexisting in the CMA molecule. Depending on the catalyst composition, different catalytic behaviors can be deduced. As expected, both Fe@C and Fe2Si@C catalyst show negligible activity for the hydrogenation of CMA (Fig. 6a and d), which indicates the iron phase is inactive in the hydrogenation of CMA and the modified Si is hardly to change this fact. However, the catalytic performance with a 40.1% CMA conversion and 24.5% yield to CMO can be obtained over the Co@C catalyst after 480 min at 60 °C (Fig. 6b). Compared with Co@C catalyst, the activity of Co2Si@C catalyst obviously increases with a conversion of 99% (Fig. 6e), which indicates the silicon atom decorated the active phase of cobalt nanoparticles. The similar results appear in the case of Ni2Si@C catalyst, the conversion of CMA increases from 46.7% to 99% after 120 min at 60 °C with the transformation of Ni@C to Ni2Si@C (Fig. 6c and f). In addition, the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts showed higher selectivity to CO in the CMA than that over the monometallic Co@C and Ni@C catalysts. During the microwave-assisted chemical vapor deposition, the overlayered carbon on metals has been destroyed, leading to the exposure of more active sites of catalysts. On the other hand, the geometric structure and electronic environment of metals have been decorated by doping the silicon atoms with more electropositive into metallic lattices, which is beneficial to the selective hydrogenation of CO bonds. Co2Si@C is moderately active while Ni2Si@C exhibits very high catalytic activity. For Co2Si@C, the generated metallic sites converted ca. 99% of CMA after 450 min. Moreover, it can be observed that the main product is CMO on Co2Si@C (Fig. 6e), while HCMA is the main reaction product on Ni2Si@C (Fig. 6f). It becomes evident that, the yield of the main product (HCMA) increases up to 81.7% after 105 min over Ni2Si@C. CMO is obtained in small amounts, while the amount of HCMO as hydrogenated product is increased, especially when 100% of CMA is converted, which indicated the HCMA further reacted with H2 to form HCMO. These results are very similar with the observations of Claus group in which Co-B and Ni-B catalysts were synthesized and the catalytic properties is probed in chemoselective hydrogenation of citral [55]. Using Co2Si@C, a conversion of CMA of 41.1% was observed after 240 min at 60 °C, and the yield of CMO was determined as 26.4%. As shown in Fig. 7 a, at this temperature CMO remained as the main product over the time span investigated, and the conversion of CMA continued to increase. HCMA and HCMO as by-products were also detected. In terms of selectivity, the situation proved to be similar at higher reaction temperatures, CMO being the main product was also observed at 70 °C during the first 240 min (Fig. 7a). However, increasing the reaction temperature up to 80 °C resulted in considerable changes. As expected, the conversion of CMA became higher, e.g. after 240 min it was only 41.1% at 60 °C but 100% at 80 °C. At 80 °C, at the beginning of the reaction, CMO was observed to be the main product, but after 240 min HCMO became the main product, which indicated the HCMA is further reacted with H2 to form HCMO (Fig. 7a and Table 3). The undesired and competing hydrogenated product (HCMA) was low. But the situation is opposite for Ni2Si@C. Ni2Si@C with higher activity for the conversion of CMA of 81.6% was observed after 90 min at 60 °C, and the yield of HCMA was observed to be 73%. As shown in Fig. 7b, the conversion of CMA increases with time at 60 °C, while HCMA remained as the main product along with the conversion of CMA. CMO and HCMO were detected with minor selectivity. In terms of selectivity, the situation proved to be similar at higher reaction temperatures, HCMA being the main product also appeared at 70 °C during the first 90 min (Fig. 7b). However, increasing the reaction temperature up to 80 °C resulted in significant changes. As expected, the conversion of CMA became higher, e.g. after 90 min it was 81.6% at 60 °C but 100% at 80 °C. At 80 °C, HCMA was observed to be the main product at the beginning of the reaction, but after 90 min HCMO increased to a large extent, which was equal in match of HCMA. It is expected that if time was extended, the HCMO will became the main product. The reaction rate to the undesired and competing hydrogenated product (CMO) was slow. The distinct selectivities for CMO and HCMA are attributed to the well-defined character of the single-phase Co2Si and Ni2Si catalysts. The results further indicate that the Co2Si@C was in favor of higher selectivity to CMO and the Ni2Si@C tended to reduce the CC bonds. It is well documented that the performance of catalytic hydrogenation of CMA is influenced by several factors, the particle sizes, the electronic structure and geometrical effects of the catalyst active site. The electronic structure of the catalyst is taken into consideration because it defines the interaction between the catalyst surface and the reactant molecule. M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) catalysts have uniform particle sizes with diameters of ca. 8–12 nm. Therefore, the influence of particle sizes in the catalytic performance of hydrogenation of CMA has been excluded. It is well-known that the CO bond is polar while the CC bond is non-polar in nature. The polar bond is more liable to adsorb on the surface of electron-enriched catalyst. From theoretical considerations and the reported reaction mechanism, the formation of CMO should be favored by enhancing the electron density of catalyst. The doping of silicon atoms with more electropositive into metals lattices can tune the electronic and geometrical structure of the catalyst active site, which is confirmed by the XPS results. Therefore, the formation of electron-enriched metal silicides leads to the higher selectivity to hydrogenate of CO bonds to form CMO than that over metal catalysts. However, due to the inherent electronic properties of metallic cobalt and nickel active sites in the metal silicides, the polar CO bonds is more liable to adsorb on the surface of electron-enriched Co2Si@C catalyst, which leads to high selectivity to chemoselective hydrogenation of CO to form CMO, while the Ni2Si@C tends to logically reduce the CC bonds. 3.3 Reaction kinetics studies of CMA hydrogenation In order to further elucidate the results in the reactivity, reactions using mixture of CMA and CMO over Co2Si@C (the third row in Scheme 4 a) catalyst and mixture of CMA and HCMA over Ni2Si@C catalyst (the third row in Scheme 4b) were carried out, respectively. The conversion of CMO over Co2Si@C was calculated using the difference between the produced amount of HCMO (0.247 mmol) and the expected amount of HCMO (0.208 mmol) from the result of the CMA hydrogenation (the first row in Scheme 4a), while the conversion of HCMA over Ni2Si@C was calculated using the difference between the produced amount of HCMO (0.166 mmol) and the expected amount of HCMO (0.087 mmol) from the result of hydrogenation of CMA (Scheme 4b, first row). The details of the calculation method for conversion are described in the supplementary material. The CMA conversion is almost the same as that in the case of CMA individually as the substrate (the first row in Scheme 4a) over Co2Si@C catalyst and Ni2Si@C catalyst respectively. But the conversion of CMO over Co2Si@C is only 8%, which is lower than that in the case of hydrogenation of CMO alone (the second row in Scheme 4a), while the conversion of HCMA over Ni2Si@C is only 4%, which is much lower than that in the case of hydrogenation of HCMA alone (the second row in Scheme 4b). These results indicate that the hydrogenation of CMA preferably took place over two catalysts and the hydrogenation of CMO over Co2Si@C and hydrogenation of HCMA over Ni2Si@C were suppressed, which are in good agreement with the fact that relatively high selectivity to CMO was observed over Co2Si@C and high selectivity to HCMA was observed over Ni2Si@C catalyst. In addition, reactions for mixed substrate of HCMA and CMA over Co2Si@C (the fourth row in Scheme 4a) and mixture of CMO and CMA over Ni2Si@C (the fourth row in Scheme 4b) were also carried out. For the Co2Si@C catalyst, the CMA conversion is close to that of HCMA, but is lower than that in the case of CMA alone (the first row in Scheme 4a). This result indicates that the hydrogenation of CO in CMA and HCMA simultaneously proceeds, which further confirms that Co2Si@C prefers selective hydrogenation of CO. From these results, the existence of CMA suppresses the hydrogenation of CMO to HCMO to a certain extent. It probably suggests that CO in CMA and HCMA can preferentially access the surface of the Co2Si@C catalyst. Different from the Co2Si@C catalyst, the CMA conversion over Ni2Si@C is lower than that of CMA alone, and the conversion of CMO is higher than expected. This result indicates that the hydrogenation of CMO is more preferable that of CMA. From these results, the existence of CMA and CMO drastically suppresses the hydrogenation of HCMA to HCMO, although the reactivity of CMA was lower than that of CMO. It probably suggests that CC in CMA and CMO can both preferentially access the surface of the Ni2Si@C catalyst. 3.4 Stability of Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts in the hydrogenation of CMA The durability and stability of catalysts play a key role in practical and industrial applications. The recycling stabilities of the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts were also investigated. The hydrogenation reaction of CMA was carried out at 60 °C and 1.0 MPa H2 over Co2Si@C for 420 min and Ni2Si@C for 105 min. After every recycle reaction, the catalyst was recovered, centrifuged, and washed with ethanol three times for the next cycle. Table 4 shows the changes of conversion of CMA and selectivity to all products during cycles for CMA hydrogenation over Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalysts, respectively. Along with stable selectivity of CMO, the conversion of CMA on Co2Si@C catalyst slightly decreased after five recyclings, but it still could reach 91.2% conversion and 63.3% selectivity to CMO. Ni2Si@C also exhibited a longer lifetime, the detected conversion of CMA decreased slightly from 95.1% to 92.2% over five successive recycles with no obvious loss of the selectivity of HCMA. These results indicated that the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C respectively sustain the robust stability in the hydrogenation of CMA. 4 Conclusions Highly dispersed transition metal silicides M2Si@C catalysts, which are embedded in porous carbon matrix, were synthesized by a facile approach via MWCVD method. The M2Si@C catalysts derived from the MOFs exhibited different catalytic performance in the chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA. Both Fe@C and Fe2Si@C catalyst show negligible activity for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. Comparing with the monometallic Co@C and Ni@C catalysts, the catalytic activity and the selective to CMO over Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C catalyst have been improved, which can be attributed that the overlayered carbon on metals has been destroyed and the geometric structure and electronic environment of metals have been decorated by doping the silicon atoms with more electropositive into metallic lattices during MWCVD processing. Due to the inherent electronic properties of metallic cobalt and nickel active sites in the metal silicides, Co2Si@C is thus chemoselective for the hydrogenation of CO bond (selectivity to CMO of ∼60% at total conversion of CMA), whereas Ni2Si@C is highly chemoselective for the hydrogenation of CC bond (selectivity to HCMA of ∼90% at total conversion of CMA). In addition, the M2Si@C nanocatalysts sustain the robust stability in the chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA. coredata.dc:description: Chemoselective hydrogenation of CC and CO bonds in the cinnamaldehyde (CMA), was successfully performed with highly dispersed transition metal silicides-embedded in the porous carbon matrix (M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni)) nanocatalysts with a particle size of 8–12 nm, which were synthesized by a facile approach via microwave-assisted chemical vapor deposition (MWCVD) using organosilane and metal-organic-framework (MOFs-74)-templated porous carbon matrix-encapsulated transition metal (M@C) precursors. Compared with M@C, the activity of M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) nanocatalysts obviously increases, which can be attributed that the overlayered carbon on metals has been destroyed during MWCVD processing, leading to the exposure of more active sites of catalysts. Due to the inherent electronic properties of metallic active sites in the metal silicides, the catalytic activity of Ni2Si@C was much higher than that of Co2Si@C and Fe2Si@C in the chemoselective hydrogenation of CMA. At total conversion of CMA, the Co2Si@C nanocatalyst was chemoselective for the hydrogenation of polar CO bonds (selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol of ∼60%), whereas Ni2Si@C nanocatalyst was highly chemoselective for the hydrogenation of non-polar CC bonds (selectivity to hydrocinnamaldehyde of ∼90%). The doping of silicon atoms with more electropositive into metals lattices in the M-Si intermetallic compounds (IMCs) influenced the adsorption of substrate molecule on the catalyst surface, slightly leading to the different reaction routes. In addition, the Co2Si@C and Ni2Si@C respectively maintain the robust stability in the hydrogenation of CMA. This result provided guidance on the design of catalyst via tuning the polarization properties of the inter-atoms in the IMCs according to the target product.
coredata.dc:title: Chemoselective hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde over MOFs-derived M2Si@C (M = Fe, Co, Ni) silicides catalysts
